IoT systems are built on a robust architecture composed of interconnected layers that ensure seamless functionality and communication. The foundation starts with physical devices equipped with sensors and actuators that gather and interact with data from their environment. Sensors collect real-time information, such as temperature, humidity, motion, or light, while actuators perform actions like opening valves, adjusting lights, or controlling motors based on processed data. These devices serve as the core components of any IoT ecosystem, capturing and acting upon data to deliver desired outcomes.



The next layer involves communication protocols that enable devices to transmit data to a central platform or directly to each other. These protocols include technologies like Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, Zigbee, and LoRa, each suited for specific use cases based on factors such as range, power efficiency, and data transfer speed. Data collected by devices is often sent to edge computing systems or cloud platforms for processing and storage. Edge computing handles data processing locally, reducing latency, while cloud platforms facilitate large-scale data storage, analysis, and remote accessibility, making IoT systems versatile and scalable.



Finally, IoT architecture incorporates software platforms that provide insights, analytics, and automation capabilities. These platforms include dashboards and APIs for visualization, machine learning algorithms for predictive analytics, and automation tools for creating smart behaviors in IoT devices. Together, these architectural components enable IoT systems to operate effectively across various industries, from agriculture and healthcare to smart cities and industrial automation, offering innovative solutions for complex challenges.
